questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the vehicle to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble while you are driving, you should stop and inspect the source of the unusual occurrence.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.answerC: By about one-quarter.
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is easier to control.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a vehicle's tires lose contact with the road surface and instead glide along on a film of water above the surface of the road.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Check the wear of the tire.
questions.answerC: Check the level of windshield wiper fluid.
questions.answerD: Check the air pressure of the tire.
questions.explanation: After a tire is changed, you should stop after a short distance to ensure that the lug nuts are still safely in place.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: The total distance traveled.
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include the following information about distance traveled: trip start and end dates; trip origin and destination points; route(s) of travel; beginning and ending odometer or hubometer readings; total distance traveled; in-jurisdiction distance; and power unit number or vehicle identification number.

questions.question: Sending text messages while driving:
questions.answerA: May be done if the messages are short.
questions.answerC: Is permitted if you are asking a question of your employer.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is prohibited.

questions.question: Most CDL holders have ____ licenses.
questions.answerC: Non-excepted
questions.explanation: Most CDL holders who drive CMVs in interstate commerce are non-excepted interstate commerce drivers.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerC: Before you start moving downhill.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: If you are not sure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure that you have enough room to safely fit underneath a bridge or other overhead object, you should slow down and seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Where can you find the tire load rating?
questions.answerA: On the inside of the driver’s door
questions.answerC: On the side of each tire
questions.explanation: A tire load rating is the maximum safe weight that can be carried by a tire at a specified pressure. This number is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter an air tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from an air tank.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Which of the following can help you determine when to upshift?
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: How many seconds of following distance per every 10 feet of vehicle should you maintain when traveling more slowly than 40 mph?
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, ensure that the brake pads are:
questions.answerC: Covered with oil.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's brakes, you should make sure the shoes and pads do not have oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, make sure your brake pads are:
questions.answerC: Covered in oil.
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerC: Use only the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: What should properly adjusted outside side flat mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see?
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, the outside side flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see along the sides of the bus; the rear tires touching the ground; and 200 feet behind the bus.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: The alternator belt.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: If you miss a student’s stop while bringing students home after school, you should:
questions.answerC: Not worry about the student.
questions.answerD: Stop quickly and let them exit.
questions.explanation: If a school bus driver forgets to stop where a student is meant to unload, the driver should not back up to the stop. Instead, they should follow established local procedures.

questions.question: Students should board a school bus:
questions.answerC: In as large a group as possible.
questions.answerD: However they want to. It makes no difference.
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly while in a single-file line and holding the handrails.

questions.question: If you must back up at a student pick-up point, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up before the students board the bus.
questions.answerB: Let the students board the bus and then back up.
questions.answerC: Let half the students board the bus and then back up toward the other half of the students.
questions.answerD: Tell the students to wait at the stop and then back toward the stop.
questions.explanation: If you must back up a school bus at a student pick-up point, be sure to pick up all students before you begin backing up. When backing, it is especially important to keep an eye out for latecomers.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching the bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Just leave the item alone and walk away.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the necessary traffic checks first.
questions.answerC: Cut off other vehicles if needed to follow the instructions.
questions.answerD: Not make the lane change if you don’t want to.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to make multiple lane changes during the driving skills test. Before changing lanes, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use proper signals. Change lanes smoothly when you can do so safely.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: Points are deducted for each pull-up.
questions.answerB: A driver is allowed three pull-ups per maneuver.
questions.answerC: A pull-up will earn points only if the driver gets out of the vehicle before pulling up.
questions.answerD: Only an excessive number of pull-ups will be counted as errors.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, there is no penalty for an initial pull-up; however, an excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: In a school bus, where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door on the passenger side of the bus
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. Its purpose is to allow the driver to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror of a school bus is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.answerD: See in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help a school bus driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerC: The emergency exits squeak.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: Outside mirrors on a school bus should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: After students board the bus.
questions.explanation: All mirrors on a school bus should be checked and adjusted before beginning a trip. Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safety of all students and surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerC: Allow your vehicle to roll.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerC: Should be done when refueling.
questions.answerD: Can be done with the driver talking to another driver.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. The process must be properly supervised and done with care.

questions.question: If equipped with flashing lights, how far in advance of a school bus stop should the bus's lights be activated?
questions.answerC: At least 200 feet
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.answerC: Next to the door.
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Wherever you can safely park.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered a look?
questions.answerA: Walking to the back of a vehicle to check its position
questions.answerB: Using side mirrors to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerC: Looking out of the driver's side window to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerD: A driver glancing over their shoulder to check blind spots
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: During exercises that are not the straight line backing exercise, you may exit your vehicle to check its position no more than:
questions.answerC: Three times.
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to result in the most student deaths per year?
questions.answerA: Students loading and unloading a school bus
questions.answerC: Accidents involving negligence
questions.answerD: Accidents in which drivers ignore traffic signals or signs
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses than while riding as passengers on board school buses.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts.
questions.answerC: The rear door of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus, the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts, and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: After driving over a bridge during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall.
questions.answerB: The color of a sign you just passed.
questions.answerC: How many lanes of traffic there were on the bridge.
questions.answerD: If there was a crosswalk on the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you drive over a bridge during the on-road driving skills test, the examiner may ask you afterwards to recall the bridge's posted weight limit.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.answerC: Three times
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: What do outside crossover mirrors allow a driver to see?
questions.answerC: The right side of the bus
questions.answerD: The left side of the bus
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a school bus driver see the danger zone area directly in front of the bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When unloading students at a school, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the ignition switch.
questions.answerB: Keep the key in the ignition and leave the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When dropping children off at a school, the bus driver should secure the bus by turning off the ignition. The driver should remove the key if they leave the driver's compartment.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Parallel park to your left.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Why should a school bus stop a short distance from students who are waiting to board?
questions.answerA: The students will have to walk to the bus, making it easier for the driver to watch their movements.
questions.answerB: The students will usually be waiting on a sidewalk.
questions.answerC: The students may get scared of a school bus coming toward them.
questions.explanation: When being stopped to load students, a school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from the waiting students. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, making it easier for the driver to keep track of their movements.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.answerC: Near a river
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.answerC: Radioactive
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening the trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Put on a pair of gloves.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.answerC: Federal regulations.
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.answerC: The Department of Energy
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a security check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.answerC: Heavy.
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.answerC: Release query
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: If a leak is suspected in a cargo of radioactive material:
questions.answerA: The driver should go to the local fire department.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up any loose pieces of the radioactive material.
questions.answerC: The driver should continue to carry the cargo, as long as they avoid touching the affected areas.
questions.answerD: The driver should not operate the vehicle until it has been cleaned.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting radioactive material and believe there is a leak or broken package in your cargo, you should tell your dispatcher or supervisor as quickly as possible. Do not touch or inhale the material. Do not use the vehicle until it has been cleaned or checked with a survey meter.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is by:
questions.answerC: Trial and error.
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.answerC: Nine
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.answerC: The destination.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: At least how many placards must be placed on a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is required to have hazardous materials placards, at least four identical placards must be displayed. These placards must be placed on the front, back, and both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.answerC: Driver information
questions.explanation: The emergency response information for a cargo of hazardous materials must include details about risks of fire or explosion associated with the materials.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerC: RQ
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.answerC: Turned on.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerC: Straps.
questions.explanation: When loading or unloading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use hooks, or any other tools that could damage containers or packaging.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.answerC: On the front
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerC: Open.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerC: Other items.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Six
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.answerC: The destination.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Solids.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.answerC: Watch for signs of leakage.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: If transporting mass explosives:
questions.answerA: The vehicle must always be placarded.
questions.answerB: The vehicle only needs to be placarded if carrying more than 200 pounds.
questions.answerC: The vehicle does not need to be placarded.
questions.answerD: Only rural roads should be used.
questions.explanation: For some hazardous materials, placards are only required to be used if 1,001 pounds or more are being carried by a vehicle. For others, including mass explosives, placards are required to be used when carrying any amount of the material.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle transporting hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: Someone other than the driver should do it.
questions.explanation: Always turn the engine off before refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials. Someone must always be at the nozzle controlling the fuel flow.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.answerC: Nine
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, a vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for long periods of time.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should never park within five feet of the traveled portion of the road. Except when parking for short periods to address vehicle necessities, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerC: Wear a chemical suit.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.answerC: A chemical suit
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is by:
questions.answerC: Trial and error.
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If you notice hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.answerD: Drive around looking for a person to repair the leak.
questions.explanation: If a cargo leak develops while you are carrying hazardous materials, do not continue driving any farther than safety requires. The farther you drive, the larger the contaminated area will become. You should park the vehicle, secure the area, and stay with the vehicle while sending someone else to get help.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerC: Made from non-ferrous materials.
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.answerC: Class 4
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.answerC: On the front
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.answerC: Release query
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Kept under the passenger’s seat.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.answerC: With sharp objects.
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the items can be distinguished by:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials being listed first.
questions.answerB: The non-hazardous materials being written in pencil.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials being listed in red ink.
questions.answerD: The hazardous materials being written larger than the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.answerC: Radioactive.
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Not apply any brake.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerC: The brakes are new.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: If you are driving and your trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerB: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.answerC: Apply the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerD: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake in an attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.answerC: Helper
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: To help prevent rollovers, you should:
questions.answerC: Keep the load near the back of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Keep the load on one side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerC: Yawning repeatedly
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: When driving a trailer with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Not depress the brakes as much as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerD: Try to not brakes as often as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: If you identify a large box in your lane on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerC: Not be worried because another vehicle will likely hit it before your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Swerve into another lane of traffic.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be very careful if you see foreign objects in your lane. Remember that even something that seems relatively light and harmless, like a cardboard box, could contain harder or heavier items that could cause damage to your vehicle.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, the engine oil pressure should come up to normal:
questions.answerC: Within three minutes.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle's engine is started, the engine's oil pressure should rise to its normal level within seconds. Do not drive a vehicle with oil pressure that is too low.

questions.question: While driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of any dangerous situation that could arise.
questions.answerC: Never look at the mirrors.
questions.answerD: Focus on your own driving and not worry about other drivers.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should consistently check the road ahead for hazards. Develop a plan to deal with any hazards that could arise.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: While driving, if you notice anything affecting safety or mechanics, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay quiet and see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Make a written report that includes your concerns.
questions.answerC: Try to fix the issue yourself.
questions.answerD: Not use that part of the vehicle and hope others don't notice the problem.
questions.explanation: At the end of each day of driving, you may be required to make a written report on the vehicle or vehicles driven. Be sure to make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: What may happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Poisonous fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerC: It may prevent proper steering.
questions.answerD: It may cause problems if the trailer is fully loaded.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can allow poisonous fumes to enter a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to regularly check your exhaust system for defects.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerC: Excess sleep
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: If you are turning left where there are two available turning lanes:
questions.answerA: It is better to take the rightmost lane.
questions.answerB: It does not matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is better to take the leftmost lane.
questions.explanation: If making a left turn where there is more than one available turn lane, you should always choose to take the rightmost lane. Large vehicles often have to swing right to make left turns, so it is safer for you to have other left-turning traffic to your left. This will allow you to have the best possible view of other turning vehicles and will lower the risk of your vehicle colliding with them.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control, or set it in the "emergency" position, when testing:
questions.answerC: The trailer service brakes.
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.answerC: After about four minutes.
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Increase the space in front of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerC: 7 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Drivers may use ____ red reflective warning triangles when their vehicle is stopped on the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Five
questions.explanation: If a vehicle carries red reflective triangles, the driver should place three of them as warning devices when the vehicle is parked on the road.

questions.question: According to a National Sleep Foundation poll, about ____ of people have driven while sleepy.
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.explanation: According to the National Sleep Foundation’s Sleep in America poll, 60 percent of Americans have driven while feeling sleepy, and 36 percent admit to having actually fallen asleep while driving.

questions.question: A vehicle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for a parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.explanation: In places where water collects on the road, it is possible for a vehicle to hydroplane. Low tire pressure or worn tire tread makes this more likely to happen. If there is enough water on a road surface, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a way to prevent drowsiness during a trip?
questions.answerA: Getting an adequate amount of sleep before driving
questions.answerC: Scheduling trips during hours when you would not normally be awake
questions.answerD: Avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you so you can take turns driving; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.answerC: Inspect the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: Low underneath clearance can cause difficulties when driving:
questions.answerC: Around corners.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross if you are pulling a trailer with low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: If a tire fails, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep one hand on the steering wheel and use their other hand to wave to other drivers.
questions.answerC: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If a tire fails, braking could cause a loss of control. Unless braking is necessary to avoid a hazard, you should stay off the brakes until your vehicle has slowed considerably. Only then should you brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

questions.question: When driving, the steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with both hands on opposite sides of the wheel.
questions.answerC: Held with both hands at the bottom of the wheel.
questions.answerD: Held with both hands at the top of the wheel.
questions.explanation: Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands, placing them on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerC: There is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerD: Vehicles are too close to one another.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver changing lanes or turning too quickly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerC: Yawning repeatedly
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Hidden under the seat.
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If you identify a large box in your lane on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerC: Not be worried because another vehicle will likely hit it before your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Swerve into another lane of traffic.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be very careful if you see foreign objects in your lane. Remember that even something that seems relatively light and harmless, like a cardboard box, could contain harder or heavier items that could cause damage to your vehicle.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerC: Driver information.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: A vehicle should be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for parked vehicles, such as flares.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles should always carry the proper emergency equipment. Be sure your vehicle is equipped with at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and warning devices for parked vehicles, such as warning triangles, fuses, or liquid burning flares.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
