questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: If you don't know if there is enough space for your vehicle to pass under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If you can't tell if your vehicle will have room to fit under a bridge or other overhead object, you should slow down and find an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Escape ramps are:
questions.answerA: Ramps to exit the interstate quickly.
questions.answerB: Ramps connecting four-lane highways and two-lane highways.
questions.answerC: Ramps that can be used by stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.answerD: Ramps that cannot be used by automobiles.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: To ensure that they are still clear.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.answerD: For the proper amount of brake fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: After a trailer starts to turn during backing, you should follow the trailer by:
questions.answerA: Doing nothing. The vehicle will follow naturally.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel farther in its current direction.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: Due to the risk of liquid surge in tanks, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve often.
questions.explanation: Be aware of the risk of liquid surge when driving tanks transporting liquid cargo. To prevent the negative affects of surge on your driving, you should start, slow, and stop very smoothly.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When a construction worker is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerC: Not drive in any lane.
questions.answerD: Wait to proceed until the construction is complete.
questions.explanation: In construction zones, do not exceed the posted safe sped limit. Slow down even more when workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: Headlights:
questions.answerA: Are not usually necessary when driving at night.
questions.answerB: Provide better light than the sun.
questions.answerC: Should be on the high beam setting whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Should always be on the high beam setting.
questions.explanation: To improve visibility, you should use high beam headlights at night where it is safe and legal to do so. However, the glare from high beam lights can blind other drivers. You should dim your lights to their low beam setting when driving within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.answerC: Be checked regularly.
questions.answerD: Be checked regularly, but only if it is cloudy.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected only if they seem frayed.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be checked for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: What is aggressive driving?
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with some regard for other motorists’ safety
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner, without regard for the rights or safety of others.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: A driver does not need to inform others of their intentions.
questions.answerB: A driver should only use turn signals if a vehicle is next to them.
questions.answerC: A driver should not use a turn signal if their lane change will be obvious.
questions.answerD: A driver should always use turn signals to inform others of their intentions.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a driver always uses proper signals to make their intentions known to others on the road.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.answerC: Coupling will be more secure.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.answerC: The driver
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop. Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerC: Cannot impair a driver.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerC: Before you start moving downhill.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.answerC: Will squeal loudly when used.
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: If you must make a quick stop while transporting liquids, one safe option is to:
questions.answerC: Apply the parking brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: A tank vehicle transporting liquids is less stable than other vehicles and may be prone to roll over or skid if not operated in a safe manner. If you must make a quick stop to avoid an accident while transporting liquid cargo, it safest to use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, what is the best way to make your vehicle more visible?
questions.answerC: Use only your clearance lights.
questions.explanation: In conditions of poor visibility (such as at dawn, at dusk, in rain, or in snow), you should turn on your low beam headlights to make your vehicle easier to see. Do not use your high beams when driving near other vehicles.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: Can be used only on a front axle.
questions.answerB: Can be used only on a trailer's axles.
questions.answerC: Should be corrected before driving.
questions.explanation: Tires on the same vehicle should all be equally sized. Ensure your tires are not mismatched when inspecting your vehicle.

questions.question: One reason for you to sign a previous driver’s vehicle inspection report is if:
questions.answerA: The previous driver dated their entry.
questions.answerB: Reported defects are certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: You plan to drive for longer than one hour or travel farther than 50 miles.
questions.answerD: The report is left on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: You should only sign a previous inspection report if defects were either noted and certified to have been repaired or if repairs were not needed.

questions.question: The maximum amount of play that is safe on a 20-inch steering wheel is:
questions.answerC: 10 inches.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel with play of more than 10 degrees may be defective. On a 20-inch wheel, this is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of the wheel.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerC: 500 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.answerC: 10 ¾ square inches
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Monitor your gauges.
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: If a tire fails while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is easier to control.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a vehicle's tires lose contact with the road surface and instead glide along on a film of water above the surface of the road.

questions.question: Before driving a bus, you must:
questions.answerA: Review its most recent inspection report.
questions.answerC: Clean the interior.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If driving in a foggy area, you should not:
questions.answerC: Use your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: It is safest not to drive in foggy areas. However, if you must drive through fog, you should slow down, use your low beam headlights and fog lights, and turn on your four-way flashers.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire:
questions.answerB: Use a B or C extinguisher.
questions.answerC: Use an X extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B and C type fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires. Water should never be used to extinguish an electrical fire because doing so could result in an electrical shock.

questions.question: Good drivers consistently look ____ seconds ahead of their vehicles.
questions.explanation: Most good drivers consistently look down the road 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Watching ahead of your vehicle will allow you to react to upcoming hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: The emergency exit door:
questions.answerA: Can be opened if the bus becomes too hot while being driven.
questions.answerB: Can be opened while the bus is being driven if the bus is carrying cargo.
questions.answerC: Can be opened to provide a better view while the bus is being backed.
questions.answerD: Should never be open while the bus is being driven.
questions.explanation: Check all emergency exits before operating a bus. Never drive a bus with an open emergency exit door or window.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerC: Soft ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: When backing, a helper:
questions.answerB: Often adds to the confusion of backing.
questions.answerC: Should only be used if the driver is not feeling confident.
questions.answerD: Would likely get in the way.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Whenever possible, use a helper who can monitor your blind spots.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerC: Drive faster.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: When you must travel down a grade, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerB: After you have already started the grade
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible
questions.answerD: At the bottom of the grade
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, you should shift into a lower gear. This will help get your vehicle to a speed that you can control without having to use your brakes too much.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.answerC: By about one-quarter.
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: During a bus ride:
questions.answerA: Carry-on baggage may be kept in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Passengers may sit in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Aisles must remain free of obstacles.
questions.answerD: Items may be placed in the aisle if passengers could easily step over them.
questions.explanation: Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in any doorway or aisle. There should be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders. Secure baggage in a way that prevents damage.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: A vehicle stopped at a green light may indicate that the driver:
questions.answerC: Does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Small amounts of a hazardous material may be transported on a bus if:
questions.answerB: There is no other way to transport the material.
questions.answerC: The passengers are notified in advance.
questions.answerD: There is no inclement weather in the forecast.
questions.explanation: Small amounts of hazardous materials may be carried on a bus if there is no other way to transport them. However, there are certain categories of materials that may not be carried on a bus in any quantity.

questions.question: If required to complete a vehicle inspection report in writing, the report must be signed:
questions.answerB: Only if defects have been noted and certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: Only if the repairs are estimated to cost more than $1,000.
questions.answerD: Only if requested to do so by a law enforcement officer.
questions.explanation: You must sign the previous vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and certified to have been repaired or not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail for one of two reasons. Which of the following is one of those reasons?
questions.answerA: There is a loss of hydraulic pressure.
questions.answerC: The brakes get too cold.
questions.answerD: The brakes are used too much in one day.
questions.explanation: Most hydraulic brake failures occur for one of two reasons. A first likely cause of brake failure is that the brakes have been overused on a downgrade, causing them to fade. The second likely cause is that there has been a loss of hydraulic pressure in the braking system. Brakes kept in good condition will rarely fail, but you should know which steps to take in case they do.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to reduce driving distractions?
questions.answerC: Eating while driving
questions.explanation: Strategies for avoiding distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Why should your mirrors be adjusted to show the road behind you as well as part of your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Having only the road in the mirrors would likely make the driver carsick.
questions.answerB: Having part of the truck in the mirrors serves as a point of reference.
questions.answerC: It is illegal to have only the road in the mirrors.
questions.answerD: The driver should be able to see the reflection of surrounding vehicles on the trailer.
questions.explanation: Part of your vehicle should be visible in your mirrors so that you have a point of reference when judging how close other drivers and objects are to your vehicle.

questions.question: If using a helper while backing a vehicle, where should they stand?
questions.answerA: In front of the passenger side
questions.answerB: In front of the driver side
questions.answerC: On the wide of the truck
questions.answerD: Near the back of the truck
questions.explanation: If you use a helper while backing your vehicle, they should stand near the back of the vehicle in a place where they are visible to you. Before backing, work out a set of hand signals that both you and your helper understand. Agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerC: Make gestures at the driver.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact and do not gesture at them. Report them to the appropriate authorities once you can safely do so.

questions.question: If one air system in a dual air brake system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully.
questions.answerC: There will be no noticeable affect.
questions.answerD: Lights on the outside of the tractor will flash.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.answerC: Three minutes.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with a single air brake system, after the engine is at operating rpms, the pressure in the air system should generally build from 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.answerC: A trap door
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with one foot on the accelerator and one foot on the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signals activate, it is essential that you bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.explanation: In an air brake system with manually operated drains, the tanks should be drained at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle with dual air brakes, pressure of ____ should be built up in the system before it is driven.
questions.answerC: 100 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Do not use the parking brake when parking if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.answerD: There is water on the ground.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait to begin driving until the air compressor builds up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: The safety valve located on the first tank opens:
questions.answerB: If there is too little pressure.
questions.answerC: If there is too much pressure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the first tank that receives compressed air has a safety valve that releases air if the pressure gets too high. It is usually set to open at 150 psi. If the valve must open, there is a fault in the system that should be repaired by a mechanic.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerC: Only effective in poor weather.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Have air pressure in the braking system even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking system when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build air pressure to allow the brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Maintain air pressure when shut off for periods of less than four hours.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerC: Are required on tractors.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: What can happen if parking brakes are used in very wet weather with temperatures below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may become too smooth to be used.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should not be used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing. The brakes could become frozen in place, making it impossible to move the vehicle.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.answerC: Gravel.
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerC: Only effective in poor weather.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerC: Will make jackknifing easier.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Used when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: In general, a tank endorsement is required to a drive tank vehicle used to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.answerC: Orange
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, what happens if one system is low on pressure?
questions.answerA: The air from the other system will be used to supplement the system with the low pressure.
questions.answerB: The front or rear brakes may not work properly.
questions.answerC: All brakes will be inoperable.
questions.answerD: The low system will use an auxiliary system to fill the tank.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared by both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.answerD: Brakes on only one side of the vehicle will work.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system consists of two separate air brake systems, connected by a single set of brake controls. Each system has its own air tanks.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerC: Are required on tractors.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to neutral.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Do not use the parking brake when parking if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.answerD: There is water on the ground.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: 75 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerC: Wood
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.answerC: Be tested before every trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerC: Move the steering wheel.
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.answerC: A trap door
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: How many air lines does a combination vehicle have?
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is better for training
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the passenger side of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Placed on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be kept as low to the ground as possible. Weight should not be placed primarily on one side of the trailer as this could make the trailer lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.answerC: On dirt roads.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerA: May lean, and could result in a rollover.
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.answerC: Have improved braking.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is placed primarily one side of a trailer, the trailer may lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerC: Will not rollover.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.answerC: Cause braking problems.
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: What is a bobtail?
questions.answerC: A tractor that goes faster than the speed limit
questions.answerD: A tractor that goes slower than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer tends to swing around.
questions.answerC: The cab will swing, but the trailer will stay straight.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerC: It doesn’t matter.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: After coupling, there should be ____ between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: A lot of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Keep cargo loose.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: When uncoupling a trailer, landing gear should be:
questions.answerC: Just off the pavement.
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand brake while experiencing a trailer jackknife will:
questions.answerC: Increase traction.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.answerC: Will squeal loudly when used.
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.answerC: When empty.
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Steer in the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.answerC: Can cause a skid.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.

questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for emergency lines?
questions.answerC: Blue
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.
